poem:
Title: "Verses on Music's Drumbeat of Time"

In this chorus of age and economy,
where concert notes tangle over golden trampolines,
illusionist millennials strum chords of midlife crises,
while Gen Z pirouettes in a raving waltz.
Baby Alphas, barely sprouted, peep curiously.
Languages of rhythm wed in this amphitheater,
resonating a melody of the times,
Between earphones and roar, silence is a forgotten score,
yet, it orchestrates the symphony of a musing poet's mind.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Governors Ball festival 2024: Coachella gets a strong, and cheaper, run for its money At least judging by the press, music festivals are having a tough time. In this economy, they have to court audiences to pay ever higher prices for an ever-more stratified experience; in a post-Beychella era, they’re in a taste war between midlife crisis millennials, Gen Z in their raving prime and the (terrifyingly) ascendant Gen Alpha, the oldest of whom are". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
